Yes, there have been several noticeable changes in the Grand Canyon since it was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Some of the key changes are:

1. Increased conservation efforts: The designation of the Grand Canyon as a UNESCO World Heritage Site has led to a greater focus on conservation efforts. There have been increased efforts to reduce waste, preserve wildlife, and protect cultural heritage sites.

2. Improved infrastructure: There have been upgrades to the park's infrastructure, including the construction of new facilities, trails, and overlooks.

3. Enhanced visitor experience: The Grand Canyon has also seen an improvement in the visitor experience. Educational programs have been established to help visitors learn about the history, geology, and ecology of the canyon. There has also been an improvement in the quality of visitor amenities and services.

4. Heightened awareness of the importance of the Grand Canyon: The designation has also helped to raise awareness of the Grand Canyon's importance as a natural and cultural wonder. This increased awareness has led to greater public support for conservation efforts and has helped to bring attention to the challenges facing the canyon.

Overall, the designation of the Grand Canyon as a UNESCO World Heritage Site has had a positive impact on the conservation and preservation of the area, as well as the visitor experience.
